definitionA: to impair the quality of; make faulty; spoil.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To spoil, make faulty; to reduce the value, quality, or effectiveness of something
   2. To debase or morally corrupt
   3. To violate, to rape
   4. To make something ineffective, to invalidate
etymology: First recorded in 1525–35; from Latin vitiātus, past participle of vitiāre “to spoil, impair,” derivative of vitium “blemish, defect, fault” + -ātus; vice 1, -ate 1
example: The result will be provisions that are watered down or loopholes that vitiate key provisions altogether.

definitionA: pertaining to, of the nature of, or caused by an earthquake or vibration of the earth, whether due to natural or artificial causes.
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Related to, or caused by an earthquake or other vibration of the Earth.
   2. Of very large or widespread effect.
example: Previous studies have noted that CO2 tends to escape Earth in seismic hot spots.

definitionA: the quality of being fragrant; a sweet or pleasing scent.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. A pleasant smell or odour.
<verb>
   1. To apply a fragrance to; to perfume.
etymology: First recorded in 1660–70; from French, from Late Latin frāgrantia. See fragrant, -ance

definitionA: first in place, order, rank, etc.:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. First, either in time or in space
   2. Most forward; front
   3. Of a higher rank or position; paramount
   4. Closest to the bow
<adverb>
   1. In front
   2. Prominently forward
   3. Especially; particularly
etymology: before 1000; fore 1 + -most; replacing Middle English, Old English formest, equivalent to form ( a ) first, variant of fruma (compare Latin prīmus ) + -est -est 1

definitionA: to pretend illness, especially in order to shirk one's duty, avoid work, etc.
definitionB:
<verb>
   1. To feign illness, injury, or incapacitation in order to avoid work, obligation, or perilous risk.
   2. To self-inflict real injury or infection (to inflict self-harm) in order to avoid work, obligation, or perilous risk.
etymology: First recorded in 1810–20; from French malingre “sickly, ailing,” equivalent to mal- “bad, ill” + Old French heingre “haggard” (perhaps from Germanic ); mal-
example: It was quick work; but Bowles had a college education—he had been only six hours a cowboy when he learned to malinger on the job.

definitionA: out of the ordinary course of nature; exceptional or abnormal:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Beyond or not conforming to what is natural or according to the regular course of things; strange.
   2. Having an existence outside of the natural world.
etymology: First recorded in 1570–80; from Medieval Latin praeternātūrālis, adjective based on Latin phrase praeter nātūram “beyond nature”; preter-, natural
example: An activist conservative and preternatural salesman, he drew national attention for his work on health care and welfare policy.

definitionA: in English, the simple past, or an instance or form of a specific verb in the simple past, such as ate or walked.
definitionB:
<noun>
   1. (grammar) The preterite tense, simple past tense: the grammatical tense that determines the specific initiation or termination of an action in the past.
<adjective>
   1. (grammar, of a tense) showing an action at a determined moment in the past.
   2. Belonging wholly to the past; passed by.
etymology: First recorded in 1300–50; Middle English, from Latin praeteritus “past, gone by,” past participle of praeterīre “to go by,” from praeter- preter- + īre “to go”; as tense name, from Latin (tempus) praeteritum “(time) past”
example: The passive voice is formed by joining the participle preterit to the substantive verb, as I am loved.

definitionA: of marriage or wedlock; matrimonial; conjugal:
definitionB:
<adjective>
   1. Of or relating to the state of being married.
etymology: First recorded in 1650–60; from Latin cōn(n)ūbiālis, equivalent to cōn(n)ūbi(um) “marriage” + -ālis adjective suffix; co-, nuptial, -al 1
example: That this revisionist myth-maker preferred not to copy Homer’s portrait of Penelope as a model of connubial chasteness hints at a larger phenomenon.
Antenuptial, an-te-nupsh′al, adj. before nuptials or marriage.
